title: The Player Behavior System Needs A Change (Written by the most banned player in the game)
body:
Before we get into things, I'm a veteran player, I've played the game for 7 years with no problems until as of late 2014. I was once high d1 before masters came out, and yes, I've become a toxic monster because of the way the community is. But I feel as if my experience in the game with probably over 20,000 games of league played in my life gives me some legitimate grounds to say something about the development of the player behavior system. I am not saying that I should be unbanned because of a player behavior system flaw, Most of my 42 permanent bans are well deserved. 

Toxicity is 9 times out of 10 an outlet for angry or upset players, whether they are upset at real life or a game. Lately, as of the end of 2014, toxicity is at an all time high. Not only is toxicity at an all time high, but the entire internet at this point has grown to be too sensitive and honestly at this point I can't stand being part of any community.

Lets review in my opinion which is one of the most unwarranted PERMANENT bans I've gotten in my life.
http://pastebin.com/3pQPAkCN [pastebin isnt visible apparently]
Now this excerpt is probably the most toxic thing I said after the whole game rolled out and I was more or less infuriated and had enough of the match
> C H: ur bad
C H: and when I say bad
C H: I mean bad as shit
C H: beyond bad
C H: atrocious
C H: you need to uninstall

Now not saying this is an okay thing to say to your teammates but this was the only thing that I said which warrants a chat restriction at most. I was permanently suspended for this game, and many others as I've had over 40 accounts banned. Back in season 3 you could literally say anything you wanted with little to no punishment, but note that SO MUCH LESS toxicity was actually present back in season 3. In CS:GO you can get away with saying the most racist, sexist, hate speech you could possibly think of, but honestly I see more toxicity in league. 

I'm sorry but people get angry when their team is thick-headed and uncooperative, you wanna know what they do in a working environment to someone who's thick headed and uncooperative? They fire them, because being thick-headed and uncooperative is just as bad as being an asshole. In a team game where nobody listens to each other anymore, and the fact that riot is so uptight about how people act in the game (Ever since Riot Lyte had a say in the behavior team) that they feel trapped. When you feel trapped, you get angry. The uncooperative players continue to see the light of day when they can get away with whatever they want and the problem never gets solved. The more cause for someone to get angry, the more toxicity surfaces in game. Back when everyone was cooperative (season 1-4) there was a huge decline in toxicity. Personally I've grown to be a VERY angry player, and I tend to lose my patients with people quick, but I give them a chance and try to ask politely, and when that doesn't work I don't want to play the game anymore.

The problem at this point will never be solved and everyone's telling me to go find a new game to enjoy. But I stick around for the amazing champions I do like (Ahri, Irelia, Renekton, Lulu, Graves, Jinx, Lucian, Syndra, Vayne, Gnar, etc.). I stick around because I played this game throughout my entire teenage years (since release in 2009). So I just continue to get new accounts and end up banned because my team wants to not cooperate. League saved my life in a way, and it helped me connect with some of the coolest people on the internet, including the girl who lives with me now and I plan to marry one day. So when I run around and say stuff like "I don't care about the game, I have the WORLD RECORD for permanent bans on league". It's a bunch of bullshit that I don't care, because I do. I miss the game for what it used to be, and I keep giving the game a chance, and riot a chance to fix the game. I may be a toxic monster spun out of control at this point but I really do care about the game. 

Sincerely,

Cheddix / Justin

Absolutely not, what I'm saying there is more mature ways of handling your stress. Hell games are suppose to be relaxing. If this game (or anything in life) is giving you that amount of stress I would suggest to probably leave the game, or at the very least take a break. I've been playing this game for possibly over 5-6 years. I've seen every amount of toxic behavior and I don't let it get to me. If/when the game stresses me out I take a break. Heck because of my work schedule I rarely play during the weekday and mainly play on the weekends!

All I'm saying is no one deserves to be treated like shit. I don't care how badly you are playing everyone has bad days. Plus people get matched up poorly with how matchmaking is so it's understandable at times.

When you look at minor toxicity like this by itself, you're right, it *appears* to not warrant a permaban.

However, that is not what resulted in your permanent ban. This was just the last straw in a long history of toxic behavior, consistently being a problem in the community.

If someone slaps you lightly once, should you get a restraining order? No, that would obviously be a gross overreaction. What if they spent every waking hour slapping everyone within arm's reach? Yes, something drastic needs to be done eventually when minor punishments have proven to have little to no effect in preventing it. This is how it works here; a punishment isn't just the result of one game usually, but is one on a path of escalation with everything on the road considered.

Some players like to say "Well, there is more toxicity in X season than Y season had". You're going to need to show something more than anecdotal evidence; you personally becoming more toxic over time doesn't reflect on the community, just you. Riot has taken great strides in improving reform of players with the Instant Feedback System and (somewhat) behavior rewards; A player will receive punishment within only 5 minutes of the triggering report, along with a reform card to help them understand where they went wrong.

If a dog shits on the floor and you hit him two hours later, all you're doing is abusing the dog. He will not learn to go outside first, he'll just learn that you enjoy hurting him. I doubt Riot would use this comparison with players, but the concept is essentially the same; people learn from their mistakes more easily if they are corrected immediately rather than when they've already forgotten what they did wrong. The Tribunal voting system was notoriously slow, and no more accurate than the IFS today.

Any player can place blame on Riot, the game, or the community, but in the end they alone are responsible for their behavior. There are tools available to them to improve their situation (such as muting), but if they refuse to use them and are a problem then Riot doesn't have any choice but to push them up that escalating path of punishment until the player decides he wants to change, or gets permabanned. Someone who gets all the way to the most severe punishment yet still does not take responsibility for their own actions has no right to say it wasn't their fault.

I already explained the whole "personal experience study" to someone else in the above comments, however regarding your last paragraph: Muting an uncooperative player or a troll isn't going to change their behavior. Riot will never fix trolling until they implement a system like CS:GO's overwatch system for cheaters. Kids who troll because they didn't get their way just get away with it and the players who tell him to fuck off get punished.

So the ultimate question was "How many times has this guy been banned?"

Just a small edit: Did anyone notice the reference I made?
42 times and counting. I don't doubt that I'll have a couple more in the future, hopefully not, but probably will.

TBH I don't really see how you can be banned that often.  I've been playing since S3, and have never received so much as a chat ban.  I am a rather mellow person though.  While I do try to tilt my opponent every now and then, I never outright insult them, and am generally nice to them after the game (sometimes offering some advice to deal with the situation).

I think it all comes down to our individual perceptions on what should and should not be allowed in the chat.  I find it reasonable for Riot to punish players for outright insulting the other players.  There's a difference between telling someone they made a mistake and telling them that they're terrible and should uninstall.  Other people consider that to be part of the fun of a sport.

Riot had to draw the line somewhere, and I think that being more conservative with it was the right call.  If incidents were to occur (suicides possibly?) even just partly as a result from the toxicity of the community and Riot wasn't doing anything about it, it could ruin them.  While this may make the game a bit less fun for those who feel the need to "vent frustration" through the chat, it is the far safer business strategy, and remains just as fun (or more fun) for those who are not so expressive.  Even still, there are plenty of people who do vent some of their frustration without being banned, so it isn't as though you can't say anything negative at all, you just have to keep yourself from taking it too far.

Like I said, it wasn't right of me to tell my teammate they were atrocious and to uninstall, I wouldve given myself a chat restriction for that. If someone legitimately is going to commit suicide if they're told they aren't good at a video game, they need to IMMEDIATELY SEEK PROFESSIONAL HELP. Things like "Kill yourself" should still be punishable.

Yeah I wasn't saying that specifically against you.  You do seem to be a bit rough on people (probably pretty rough at times), but I feel like you have your limits.  This was more an explanation of why I think Riot takes such a stance on toxicity in the game.

The suicide part was a bit exaggerated, but it could entirely happen with a community this massive.

Honestly with unstable people, even not smiling at them as you walk past them on the street could trigger a suicidal thought, I've been down the road previously and at that point you need some help. Yes, I get rough with people, quite rough out of anger. But when I'm content I'm all for improving the community as a whole. Me being so toxic, is part of the problem, but I can't improve by myself, I want the entirety of league of legends to improve with me. There wouldn't be a need for toxicity if we dealt with uncooperative people.

Citation required for something I'm saying out of personal experience to a high degree? Now you're just being ridiculous.

You make a claim. It is an overall claim about the global state of the game. Based on "personal experience" it is worthless as a metric.

If crime rates are down, even very considerably, but you ask a person who just got mugged about them, they will tell you crime is on the rise. Because that is their personal experience, even if it goes counter to reality.

Making claims like the ones I quoted and coming to conclusions based on them is very risky if your source is personal experience. We have tons of various cognitive biases. One simple bias that needs to be accounted for is rosy retrospection. You notice how everything was always better in good old times? Was there really less toxicity back in S3 or is it just how your remember it? And that is just example from the top of my head.

Hence the need for  citation, yes. At least if we want serious discussion rather then complaints about how everything was better back in good old days.

I'll debunk your second paragraph right now. It's not that I just got out of a single game where people were toxic, or I was toxic. This has been a build up from the past two years, and I've recognized it, it may be worthless as a metric but open your eyes. If I were to survey 20 players who have been playing as long as I have, they would say the same thing. I've had at least 5 people in the past month tell me they miss season 3. Unlike most of the community, I don't mute people when I get annoyed, so I see the whole story every game.

*Shrug.* Whatever.

I'll just leave you with a story. It is a very real one. There is a decently big movement that claims vaccines cause autism and hence its member are strongly opposed to vaccination. The claim has been investigated by scientist in multiple studies. Those studies failed to find a link between autism and vaccines.

However members of the movement, based on their personal experience, claim to KNOW that vaccines cause autism and every study that tells that it is not so is a part of conspiracy to hide the truth.

I am happy however that your personal experiences are perfectly reliable and can not be result of cognitive bias or distorted memory. Good to have reasonable, rational people with solid sources of their claims in the community.

> _Shrug_. Whatever. 


Lmao Your argument dies right there.

I have long given up on trying to reason with people who have their mind made up from the start. I can write essays about why using personal experience as metric is flawed. And then get answered "but this is what I feel from my games" over and over again.

If you feel that he won the discussion just cause after making my point once I don't keep going in circles... *Shrug* Whatever.

Here's the thing, regardless of personal experience in the whole "Vaccines cause autism" movement, they don't visually see the chemicals in their brain being effected by the vaccine, and it was proven wrong by scientists. In the case of the game being more toxic, and the fact that I've been steadily playing multiple games on a daily basis, I've more or less done a mental study on the players of the game. Not to mention there's been no study to prove that we have significantly less toxicity since the changes to the system. Two different scenarios. Keep trying to prove yourself right buddy, but it's not going to solve the problem at hand.

A player who is actually bad enough for me to call them bad, would be something like 0/10. And despite them creating an extremely frustrating experience- being 0/10, directly giving me loss, taking away earned LP, and wasting at least 30 mins of my time, I would call them "bad". While regularly hearing insults of "autism", "kill yourself", etc, I didn't think "bad" could even be considered punishable.
Some people need to hear it the harsh way before they can realize "Hey, maybe I'm the one making the mistake and it's not my team's fault why I got solokilled in lane".
